diagnostics.description: System has insufficient refrigerant charge, typically due to a leak or improper charging.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Reduced capacity, longer runtimes, possible coil frosting, poor comfort.
common_root_causes: Refrigerant leak at joints or coils
System not charged correctly at installation
Service leak not repaired before recharging
canonical_symptoms: Poor cooling performance
Some rooms never reach setpoint
Frost or ice on suction line or indoor coil
diagnostics.notes: In the field this is often lumped together as 'low on charge' regardless of exact leak location.
evidence_snippets: Signs of low refrigerant include poor cooling performance and ice forming on the coils or suction line:contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}.
Field studies found that improper refrigerant charge was present in over half of inspected AC systems:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}.

diagnostics.description: System has too much refrigerant (overcharged), leading to abnormally high pressures and inefficiency.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: High head pressure, reduced efficiency, potential compressor overheating, possible reduced cooling.
common_root_causes: System overcharged during service
Incorrect refrigerant added to 'fix' cooling problem
Non-condensable gases present
canonical_symptoms: System struggles to cool despite everything running
Abnormally high discharge pressure readings
Compressor running hot
diagnostics.notes: Ironically, overcharging can reduce cooling capacity and put extra stress on the compressor due to high pressure.
evidence_snippets: An overcharged system is characterized by high pressures (high head and suction) and can actually have reduced cooling capacity:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}.

diagnostics.description: Air or other non-condensable gases are present in the sealed refrigerant circuit.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Elevated condensing pressure, reduced cooling efficiency, and potential compressor strain.
common_root_causes: System not evacuated properly (air left inside)
Leak repaired without pulling deep vacuum
Wrong service procedures introducing air
canonical_symptoms: System pressure readings outside normal range
Erratic cooling performance
Hissing/gurgling in system (if moisture freezing at TXV)
diagnostics.notes: Non-condensables typically require recovering refrigerant and evacuating the system to remove them.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Thermal expansion valve stuck or failed
diagnostics.description: The thermostatic expansion valve (TXV) is malfunctioning, causing incorrect refrigerant flow into the evaporator.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Evaporator may be starved (low cooling, potential coil icing) or flooded (risk of liquid carryover to compressor).
common_root_causes: Debris or moisture blocking the TXV
TXV sensing bulb charge lost
Mechanical failure of valve components
canonical_symptoms: Evaporator coil starved or freezing up
Inconsistent cooling and superheat readings
Possible compressor noise (liquid slugging) if flooding
diagnostics.notes: A failed TXV can often be confirmed by abnormal pressure/temperature readings and may require replacement.
evidence_snippets: A malfunctioning TXV can starve or flood the evaporator. In some cases, liquid refrigerant may flood back to the compressor (slugging) if the valve is stuck open:contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Filter drier or capillary tube restriction
diagnostics.description: A restriction in the liquid line (often at the filter-drier or capillary tube) impedes refrigerant flow.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Starved evaporator, low suction pressure, potential frosting at or before the restriction, reduced cooling output.
common_root_causes: Debris or desiccant from filter-drier clogging the line
Moisture in system freezing at the metering device
Mechanical blockage or kink in capillary tube
canonical_symptoms: Little or no cooling despite compressor running
Frost buildup right before the restriction point
Low suction and head pressures
diagnostics.notes: A restricted filter-drier will often be noticeably colder on the outlet side. Resolution involves replacing the clogged component and evacuating the system.

diagnostics.description: The compressor fails to start due to an electrical issue (e.g., failed start components or lack of power to the compressor).
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: No cooling (compressor does not run), although the outdoor fan might run; system may hum then shut off.
common_root_causes: Failed start capacitor or start relay
Compressor contactor not engaging
Compressor motor locked (drawing locked-rotor amps)
canonical_symptoms: AC hums but no cooling (compressor not running)
Circuit breaker may trip during compressor start attempts
Outdoor unit fan runs but air is not cold inside
diagnostics.notes: Technician may find the compressor drawing locked rotor amperage (LRA) or hear a humming/clicking sound. Replacing capacitors or the compressor itself could be required.
evidence_snippets: If the indoor blower motor fails or doesn't run, no air circulates through the home. You might hear the system humming, but no air comes out of the vents:contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}.

diagnostics.description: The compressor runs but has internal mechanical damage or leaking valves, severely reducing its ability to pump refrigerant.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Greatly reduced cooling capacity (or none at all) despite the compressor running; system may never reach setpoint and may run continuously.
common_root_causes: Wear and tear or high heat causing compressor valve damage
Liquid slugging events damaging pistons/scrolls
Loss of lubrication leading to internal scoring
canonical_symptoms: Minimal cooling even though compressor is on
Compressor sounds unusually quiet or runs with little temperature difference in lines
Both high and low side pressures equalize quickly
diagnostics.notes: Internal compressor failures often manifest as a "running but not pumping" scenario. The only remedy is typically compressor replacement.

diagnostics.description: In a heat pump, the reversing valve is not switching or sealing properly, causing the system to be stuck in one mode or to leak refrigerant flow between modes.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Heat pump may be unable to switch from cooling to heating (or vice versa), or performance is degraded due to refrigerant bypass (cooling and heating happening simultaneously to some extent).
common_root_causes: Solenoid coil failure (valve not shifting)
Internal mechanical failure or debris in valve
Valve slide leaking internally due to wear
canonical_symptoms: Heat pump stuck in cooling (or heating) mode regardless of thermostat
In cooling, supply air is not cold (or in heating, not hot) because valve is mid-position or leaking
Audible changeover 'whoosh' may not occur when reversing mode
diagnostics.notes: Sometimes tapping on a stuck reversing valve can temporarily free it, but replacement is usually needed for a permanent fix if the valve is malfunctioning.

diagnostics.description: The compressor turns on and off too frequently in short intervals, not completing normal cycles.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Inefficient operation, poor dehumidification, and increased wear on the compressor. Indoor comfort may suffer due to temperature swings.
common_root_causes: Oversized system reaching setpoint too fast
High pressure cut-out or low pressure cut-out repeatedly stopping compressor (underlying cause)
Thermostat or control issues causing rapid cycling
canonical_symptoms: Air conditioner cycles every few minutes
Temperature fluctuates as system turns off quickly
Compressor relay clicking frequently
diagnostics.notes: Short cycling drastically reduces efficiency and strains the compressor. Technicians will look for control issues or whether the unit is oversized for the space.
evidence_snippets: Oversized AC units will short cycle because they satisfy the thermostat too quickly:contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}.

diagnostics.description: The HVAC system's air filter is loaded with dirt and debris, restricting airflow through the system.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Significantly reduced airflow, leading to poor cooling/heating performance. In cooling, can cause coil icing; in heating, can cause furnace overheating.
common_root_causes: Infrequent filter replacement or cleaning
High dust environment or construction debris accumulation
Using an overly restrictive filter longer than its service life
canonical_symptoms: Weak airflow at vents
Evaporator coil icing (in cooling mode)
Furnace overheats or shuts off
diagnostics.notes: This is one of the most common issues and easiest fixes: replacing a dirty filter can immediately restore airflow and proper operation.
evidence_snippets: A clogged air filter dramatically restricts airflow, which can cause the evaporator coil to freeze up and the furnace's heat exchanger to overheat:contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}.

diagnostics.description: The indoor evaporator coil is fouled with dust, dirt, or biological growth, impeding airflow and heat exchange.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Reduced cooling capacity and efficiency; can lead to excessively low coil temperature and eventual icing of the coil.
common_root_causes: Running with a missing or ineffective air filter
Filter bypass air carrying dust onto coil
High humidity causing dust to stick and microbial growth on coil
canonical_symptoms: Reduced airflow through coil
Evaporator coil freezing up
Insufficient cooling
diagnostics.notes: Cleaning the evaporator coil (chemically or with steam/vacuum) can restore performance. Prevent by maintaining clean filters and proper filtration.
evidence_snippets: Dust and dirt on the evaporator coil insulate it and restrict airflow, often leading to a frozen coil and reduced cooling:contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Blower motor failure or fan not running
diagnostics.description: The indoor blower (air handler/furnace fan) is not operational due to motor or electrical failure, resulting in no circulation of air.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: No air flows through the ducts. In cooling, the evaporator coil may freeze due to zero airflow; in heating, the furnace may overheat and trip safety limits.
common_root_causes: Blower motor burned out or seized
Blower capacitor failure (for PSC motors)
No power or signal to motor (control board or relay issue)
canonical_symptoms: No air coming from vents even though AC/furnace is on
Outdoor unit runs but no indoor airflow
Furnace fires but shuts off on high limit (blower never came on)
diagnostics.notes: If the blower motor fails, often the system will shut down cooling to prevent icing (via freeze stat or coil freeze) or shut off burner via limit. Replacement of the motor or its capacitor is usually required.
evidence_snippets: If the indoor blower motor fails or doesn't run, no air circulates through the home. You might hear the system humming, but no air comes out of the vents:contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}.

diagnostics.description: Major leaks or a disconnected duct in the air distribution system are causing conditioned air to escape before reaching the living space.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Some or all rooms receive insufficient airflow, leading to weak or no cooling/heating in certain areas. The system runs longer and efficiency drops.
common_root_causes: Detached or broken duct in attic/crawlspace
Large gaps or holes in ductwork from damage or poor installation
Failed duct seals at plenum or register connections
canonical_symptoms: Some rooms not cooling/heating at all
Weak airflow in distant parts of the house
High energy bills due to conditioned air loss
diagnostics.notes: Duct leakage often results in hot or cold spots in the house. A duct blaster or visual inspection can identify the leak points. Repairing ducts can greatly improve performance.
evidence_snippets: Leaky or disconnected ductwork means that conditioned air never reaches some rooms, diverting cold air away:contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}.

diagnostics.description: The ductwork or vents are too small or obstructed, limiting the volume of air that can flow to certain areas.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Reduced airflow to some rooms (or whole house if return is undersized), causing poor comfort and potentially noisy high-velocity airflow (whistling). System may run longer to compensate.
common_root_causes: Improper HVAC design (duct diameter too small for airflow)
Many supply vents closed or blocked by furniture
Collapsed or heavily kinked flex duct
canonical_symptoms: One or more rooms consistently under-conditioned
Noticeable whistling noise at vents
Higher static pressure readings in duct system
diagnostics.notes: Addressing this might involve opening closed registers, removing obstructions, or in serious cases re-sizing ductwork. A quick clue is often a room with a closed vent or a rug over a return grille.
evidence_snippets: Closed or blocked vents and undersized ductwork restrict airflow, which can cause certain rooms to receive very little air:contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Blower running at wrong speed or dirty blower wheel
diagnostics.description: The indoor blower is not delivering its rated airflow because it’s set to an incorrect speed tap or its fan wheel is coated with dirt.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Lower-than-intended airflow can cause inadequate cooling or heating distribution and may contribute to coil icing or furnace overheating.
common_root_causes: Blower motor connected to wrong speed tap (installer or repair error)
Significant dust accumulation on blower blades reducing its efficiency
ECM programming or dip switches set for incorrect airflow
canonical_symptoms: Generally weak airflow even with a clean filter and proper ductwork
Better performance after blower wheel cleaning
High static pressure despite clean filter (indicating blower issue)
diagnostics.notes: HVAC techs follow the "Air Before Charging" principle (ABCs) because airflow issues should be resolved (like correct blower speed and clean fan) before diagnosing refrigerant charge.

diagnostics.description: The outdoor condenser coil is coated with dirt or obstructed by debris, impeding the system’s ability to reject heat.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Elevated head pressures, reduced cooling capacity, longer runtimes, and potential compressor overheating or high-pressure trips on very hot days.
common_root_causes: Lack of maintenance (coil not cleaned for years)
Outdoor debris like cottonwood, leaves, grass clippings clogging fins
Condenser placed in a location with restricted airflow or recirculating hot air
canonical_symptoms: AC cannot keep up on hot days
High discharge pressure readings
Condenser unit extremely hot
diagnostics.notes: The coil may need to be washed with water or coil cleaner. Homeowners should ensure the area around the condenser is clear of obstructions and clean the coil annually.
evidence_snippets: If the outdoor condenser coil is dirty or clogged, it cannot reject heat effectively, resulting in reduced cooling output and potentially causing the unit to overheat:contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}.

diagnostics.description: The outdoor fan responsible for drawing air through the condenser coil is not running due to a failed motor or related component, so the condenser has little to no airflow.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Without the condenser fan, head pressure skyrockets and the compressor will overheat or trip on high pressure, resulting in loss of cooling and potential compressor damage if it continues.
common_root_causes: Fan motor burnout or seized bearings
Failed run capacitor for the fan motor
Broken fan blade or obstruction preventing rotation
canonical_symptoms: Outdoor unit runs (compressor hums) but fan isn’t spinning
AC runs briefly then shuts off (high pressure trip)
Possible burning smell or the unit is extremely hot to touch
diagnostics.notes: In some cases, you might see the fan blade twitch or spin slowly if the capacitor is bad. A tech will test the capacitor and motor continuity. This fault requires immediate attention to prevent compressor damage.
evidence_snippets: A telltale sign of a bad capacitor is a humming noise without the fan or compressor actually starting:contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}. The motor may try to start and fail.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Condenser fan running slow (capacitor or bearings)
diagnostics.description: The outdoor fan is running at a reduced speed due to a weak capacitor or mechanical drag (e.g., worn motor bearings), resulting in suboptimal condenser airflow.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Moderately elevated head pressures and reduced efficiency. The AC may work under light conditions but struggle or trip in high ambient temperatures due to insufficient condenser cooling.
common_root_causes: Aging or weak run capacitor not providing full torque
Motor bearings are worn causing friction
Voltage supply to motor is low (brownout or wiring issue)
canonical_symptoms: Condenser fan needs a push to start spinning
Fan speed visibly lower than normal (air out of top is weak)
AC works in cooler weather but overheats/shuts off on very hot days
diagnostics.notes: Often, replacing the capacitor resolves slow fan issues. If the motor itself is failing (bearings), replacing the motor is needed. Technicians will also ensure the fan blade is properly secured and not rubbing.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Outdoor unit airflow obstructed (debris or cover)
diagnostics.description: The condenser’s airflow is impeded by external obstructions such as debris buildup around the unit or an improperly placed cover.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Similar to a dirty coil: heat can’t be rejected effectively. The system may overheat or have reduced capacity, especially in high outdoor temperatures, potentially tripping high-pressure safety.
common_root_causes: Leaves, plastic bags, or other objects blocking condenser intake
Bushes or structures placed too close to unit
Condenser left covered or wrapped while running
canonical_symptoms: Poor cooling on hot days until debris is cleared
Condenser fan air discharge feels very weak or hot due to recirculation
Possibly compressor cycling off on safety until obstruction removed
diagnostics.notes: Clearing the area around the outdoor unit is often an easy fix. Units should have at least 1-2 feet of clearance around and above for proper airflow.

diagnostics.description: The primary power supply to the HVAC system has been interrupted by a blown fuse or a tripped circuit breaker, cutting power to some or all components.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The HVAC system (or a major component like the outdoor unit) will not operate at all. There may be no signs of life (no fan, no compressor, no display on thermostat if it shares the circuit).
common_root_causes: Over-current due to a shorted component (e.g., motor or compressor locked rotor)
Electrical surge or lightning strike
Aging breaker that trips below its rated current
canonical_symptoms: System completely unresponsive (no cooling/no heating)
Thermostat might be blank if on same circuit
Breaker found in the OFF position or fuse visibly blown
diagnostics.notes: After restoring a tripped breaker or replacing a fuse, it’s crucial to monitor if it trips again. Repeated trips indicate an underlying electrical fault that needs addressing.
evidence_snippets: If nothing happens when the AC should turn on, check the breakers or fuses. A tripped circuit breaker is a common cause of an AC unit not turning on:contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Main power switch or disconnect off
diagnostics.description: The HVAC system’s main power switch (indoor furnace switch or outdoor disconnect) is turned off, meaning the equipment is not powered.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The system appears completely dead: no blower, no compressor activity, no response at all to thermostat demands.
common_root_causes: Accidental shutoff (service tech or homeowner forgot to turn back on)
Emergency switch activated (e.g., someone toggled it or a float switch wired to it tripped)
Disconnect pulled for maintenance and not reinserted
canonical_symptoms: HVAC system not running at all, no noise or airflow
Thermostat may be blank if it relies on that power
Upon inspection, power switch found in OFF position
diagnostics.notes: This is often a quick fix: simply restoring the power. The more important step is determining why it was off (maintenance, safety trip, etc.) to ensure it's safe to turn back on.
evidence_snippets: Sometimes the outdoor unit's emergency disconnect switch or the furnace power switch is turned off by accident, which will prevent the system from running:contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}.

diagnostics.description: The low-voltage transformer (typically 120V/240V to 24V) has failed or a low-voltage fuse is blown, resulting in loss of 24-volt control power.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The thermostat and control circuits are unpowered. The system will not respond to any commands (no relays or valves actuating, thermostat may be blank if it doesn’t have batteries).
common_root_causes: Secondary short (e.g., contactor coil shorted, causing fuse to blow)
Transformer overheated due to overload or short circuit
Power surge damaged transformer
canonical_symptoms: Thermostat display is blank (if no battery backup)
No click or response when calling for heat/cool
24V AC absent on control board test points
diagnostics.notes: The fix often involves identifying and correcting the cause of the overload (e.g., shorted wires) and then replacing the transformer or fuse. Simply replacing the fuse/transformer without fixing the root cause will result in repeat failure.

diagnostics.description: One of the capacitors (start or run) that provide the necessary phase shift to start and run the compressor or fan motor has failed or weakened significantly.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The associated motor (compressor or fan) struggles to start or doesn’t start at all. Often just a humming sound is heard while the motor fails to turn, and the system may shut down on overload.
common_root_causes: Age and heat causing the capacitor to degrade (electrolyte dries out)
Power surge damaging the capacitor
Motor issue causing capacitor to be overstressed
canonical_symptoms: Outdoor unit hums but fan doesn’t spin until manually kick-started
Compressor tries to start (lights dim) then cycles off without running
Bulged or leaking capacitor visible on inspection
diagnostics.notes: Replacing the faulty capacitor usually restores normal operation instantly. It's a quick and common repair. It's also one of the first things checked when a motor won’t start but is receiving power.
evidence_snippets: A telltale sign of a bad capacitor is a humming noise without the fan or compressor actually starting:contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}. The motor may try to start and fail.

diagnostics.description: The high-voltage contactor (relay) that controls power to the compressor and/or outdoor fan is defective – possibly stuck open (not energizing circuit) or stuck closed (unable to disengage).
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: If stuck open, the compressor (and maybe fan) will not turn on at all despite the coil being energized. If stuck closed, the compressor/fan may run continuously even when not commanded. In either case, cooling/heating is affected and safety can be an issue if stuck closed.
common_root_causes: Contact surfaces pitted or welded from electrical arcing over time
Coil burn-out (contactor never pulls in)
Insect or debris lodged in contactor preventing motion
canonical_symptoms: Outdoor unit never comes on (no compressor/fan) despite thermostat call
Outdoor unit runs nonstop until breaker is turned off
Chattering or clicking sounds from contactor area
diagnostics.notes: Contactors are relatively inexpensive and often replaced during repairs. A telltale of a stuck contactor is an outdoor unit that runs even when thermostat is off (stuck closed) or one that doesn’t run even though 24V is present at the coil (stuck open).
evidence_snippets: A failed contactor can prevent the outdoor unit from turning on at all, or cause it to stick on. For example, a contactor stuck open means the compressor and fan never get power:contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}.

diagnostics.description: One or more electrical connections in the HVAC system are loose, oxidized, or otherwise not making good contact, causing intermittent operation or failure of components due to voltage drops or open circuits.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The effect can vary from intermittent shut-offs and failures to start, to components (like motors) receiving lower voltage and overheating. It can manifest as random system outages or unreliable performance.
common_root_causes: Vibration causing screw terminals to loosen over time
Corrosion or oxidation on terminals (especially in humid or coastal environments)
Rodent damage partially severing a conductor
canonical_symptoms: System works sometimes and then doesn’t, seemingly at random
Visible charring or discoloration at a connector
Wiggling a wire or tapping a component causes system to cut in/out
diagnostics.notes: Electrical connection issues often require careful inspection of wires at the contactor, circuit board, and other components. Tightening screws and cleaning contacts can resolve many of these issues.
evidence_snippets: Worn or damaged wires and loose connections can cause the system to lose power or work intermittently:contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}.

diagnostics.description: The system’s control board (or furnace/air handler integrated circuit board) has malfunctioned due to component failure or firmware issues.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The HVAC system may not operate at all, or may behave erratically (e.g., blower or outdoor unit not being commanded on, or stuck on). Diagnostic LEDs might indicate a board fault. Essentially, the 'brain' isn’t sending proper signals.
common_root_causes: Electrical surge or lightning strike damaging circuits
Transformer over-voltage or short sending high voltage to low-voltage circuits
Component failure on the board (e.g., relay, resistor, solder joint) due to age or heat
canonical_symptoms: No response from system even though high voltage power is present (no outputs being energized)
Furnace blower or other component stuck ON continuously (relay welded on board)
Diagnostic LED on board showing error code or not lighting at all
diagnostics.notes: Replacing the control board is often the solution after verifying that all sensors and peripheral devices are functional. It's also critical to ensure the root cause (like a short that fried the board) is resolved to avoid repeat failure.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Voltage supply problem (brownout or phase loss)
diagnostics.description: The HVAC equipment is experiencing incorrect supply voltage: either consistently low voltage (brownout) or the loss of one phase in a three-phase system, leading to improper motor operation.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Motors (compressors, fans) may fail to start or run very hot due to undervoltage or missing phase. The system may trip overload protectors or not operate at full capacity. Severe phase imbalance can quickly burn out three-phase motors.
common_root_causes: Utility brownout during peak load times
Blown fuse on one leg of a three-phase supply or utility phase outage
Voltage drop due to undersized wiring or excessive distance
canonical_symptoms: Compressor hums loudly but doesn't start (in low voltage conditions)
Three-phase motor vibrating or not running (single-phasing)
Lights dimming in the building when AC tries to start
diagnostics.notes: Many commercial units have phase monitors that will shut the system off in event of phase loss or reversal. In residential settings, brownouts can cause relays to chatter and motors to overheat. The power company or an electrician may need to address supply issues.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Blower or fan motor shorted (burned out)
diagnostics.description: A motor (either indoor blower or outdoor fan) has electrically failed, either by shorting internally or the winding has opened, causing it not to run and often blowing fuses or tripping breakers.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The affected fan will not operate at all. If it’s the indoor blower, no airflow; if it’s the outdoor fan, the compressor may trip off on high pressure quickly. A direct short may blow a fuse instantly when the motor circuit is energized.
common_root_causes: Motor overheated (e.g., due to overcurrent or lack of maintenance) and insulation failed
Bearings seized causing motor stall and burnout
Water ingress into motor windings (shorting it)
canonical_symptoms: Associated fan does not run at all (no movement, no sound from motor)
Breaker trips or fuse blows whenever motor is supposed to turn on
Burning smell or smoke when motor attempted to start
diagnostics.notes: Resolution involves replacing the motor. The technician will also verify that the mechanical load (fan blade, blower wheel) turns freely and that the capacitor is good, to ensure the new motor isn't immediately stressed.

diagnostics.description: The compressor’s internal thermal overload protector is tripping because the compressor is running too hot, often due to stressful conditions or another fault.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The compressor will shut off (or refuse to start) intermittently. Cooling will stop until the compressor cools and the overload resets. This can manifest as the AC working for a short period then the outdoor unit stopping, possibly cycling in this manner.
common_root_causes: High head pressure (dirty condenser, overcharge) causing overheating
Low charge leading to inadequate motor cooling (in hermetic compressors, refrigerant cools the motor)
Voltage issues or hard start issues causing long start times and heat buildup
canonical_symptoms: AC cools initially then stops cooling as compressor cuts out
Compressor extremely hot to the touch after shutdown
System may short-cycle as compressor repeatedly tries and fails once overheated
diagnostics.notes: A thermal overload trip is a protective measure. The key is identifying why the compressor overheated: could be dirty coils, loss of charge, or something like a failing start capacitor causing long run times at high amps.
evidence_snippets: An undercharge of refrigerant can cause the compressor to overheat and no longer operate properly (e.g. short cycles on low pressure cut-out or runs continuously):contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}.

diagnostics.description: The thermostat was not set to the desired mode or temperature for conditioning (e.g., it might be set to heating or off when cooling is expected, or the setpoint is misadjusted).
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The HVAC system does not run in the expected mode. For example, cooling won’t come on if thermostat is in heat mode, or the system remains off if the setpoint isn’t reached due to a mis-set temperature.
common_root_causes: User error (thermostat accidentally set to the wrong mode or schedule changes)
Children or other occupants changing settings
Thermostat defaulting to an energy-saving mode that wasn’t noticed
canonical_symptoms: System not cooling or heating when expected, with thermostat reading a mode that doesn’t call for it
Thermostat shows the wrong mode (e.g. 'heat' instead of 'cool') or an unreasonably high/low setpoint
HVAC system does nothing because it’s actually turned off at the thermostat
diagnostics.notes: This is a very common non-problem: always double-check the thermostat settings first. Simply switching to the correct mode or adjusting the setpoint resolves the issue.
evidence_snippets: Something as simple as incorrect thermostat settings can mimic a system problem. It's important to ensure the thermostat is actually calling for cooling or heating as appropriate:contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}.

diagnostics.description: The thermostat is not functioning properly – it may not register the correct temperature or its controls may not engage the HVAC system, despite being set correctly.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The HVAC system may not turn on or off as commanded. This can lead to no heating/cooling or continuous running. Comfort is impacted because the control point of the system is not behaving as intended.
common_root_causes: Internal failure of thermostat electronics or sensors
Software glitch or firmware issue in smart thermostats
Calibration drift causing inaccurate temperature readings
canonical_symptoms: Thermostat display on but HVAC does not respond to changes
Thermostat reading different from actual room temperature by a significant margin
System short cycles or runs too long due to faulty thermostat signals
diagnostics.notes: Replacing the thermostat is a straightforward fix if it's determined to be faulty. For smart thermostats, sometimes a reset or firmware update can resolve issues if it's software-related.
evidence_snippets: An incorrect temperature reading can cause your system to run too much or not enough, leading to discomfort and wasted energy:contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Thermostat batteries dead or no power
diagnostics.description: The thermostat has lost power, either due to drained batteries (in battery-powered models) or loss of 24V supply (in hard-wired models), causing it to go blank or offline.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The HVAC system will not receive any commands to turn on or off. Essentially, the system may remain off because the 'brain' (thermostat) isn't functioning. If the thermostat is blank, it’s obvious; if it's just not powered enough to close relays, it quietly fails to control.
common_root_causes: Batteries in thermostat depleted
Blown fuse or transformer issue removing 24V power
C-wire not connected on a smart thermostat that lost battery backup
canonical_symptoms: Thermostat display is blank or unresponsive
No heating/cooling even if you try to adjust the thermostat
Replacing thermostat batteries immediately restores display and control
diagnostics.notes: Always check if the thermostat has power during a no-heat or no-cool call. Many service calls are resolved by simply replacing thermostat batteries or flipping a furnace service switch back on.
evidence_snippets: If a digital thermostat goes blank, the HVAC system won't run. Often this is due to dead batteries or a loss of 24V power to the thermostat:contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}.

diagnostics.description: The low-voltage wiring between the thermostat and HVAC equipment is incorrect (miswired) or a connection has come loose/undone, so signals are not properly reaching the equipment or are activating the wrong functions.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Possibly no response from HVAC to thermostat, or wrong equipment turning on. For example, the heat might come on when calling for cool (common if O/B reversing valve wire mixed up), or nothing happens at all due to an open circuit.
common_root_causes: Incorrect thermostat hookup (e.g., after thermostat replacement or new system install)
A wire has come off a terminal screw due to poor tightening
Physical damage to thermostat cable (rodent chewing or during renovations)
canonical_symptoms: Thermostat calls but HVAC doesn’t engage (open circuit)
Heat pump cools in heat mode or vice versa due to miswired O/B
Fan runs but compressor doesn’t (or other mis-combinations) because of wiring errors
diagnostics.notes: This often occurs after DIY thermostat replacements. The fix is to correct the wiring per the standard connections (e.g., R to R, W to W, Y to Y, etc., including heat pump specific O/B). Ensure wires are firmly attached.
evidence_snippets: Miswired or loose thermostat connections can cause the system to not respond properly. For example, a wrong connection on a heat pump thermostat can have the heat running during a call for cool:contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Cooling disabled or heat on inadvertently
diagnostics.description: Cooling mode is not actually running because either the system is intentionally or unintentionally in the wrong mode (heat or off), or an auxiliary heat source is running concurrently, causing warm air output even when cooling is expected.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The user experiences warm air from the vents despite expecting cooling. Essentially, cooling is not active - either because it's turned off at controls or because heat is counteracting it.
common_root_causes: Thermostat mistakenly left in heat mode or turned off
Heat pump wired incorrectly (O/B reversal, causing heat mode when calling cool)
Auxiliary electric heat stuck on due to a relay fault, overpowering cooling
canonical_symptoms: AC is blowing hot/warm air instead of cold
No cooling effect though system seems to be on
Thermostat mode found set to heating or fan-only by accident
diagnostics.notes: Often the solution is simply to switch the thermostat to the correct mode. In case of wiring issues (like a heat pump O/B issue), a quick rewiring fixes the reversed operation.
evidence_snippets: Are your thermostat settings correct? If it's accidentally set to heat or the fan-only setting, the AC won’t cool:contentReference[oaicite:23]{index=23}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Thermostat or control schedule causing off periods
diagnostics.description: The thermostat’s programmed schedule or smart features are setting the system in a way that conflicts with occupant comfort (e.g., setting the temperature higher during certain periods, making it seem like the HVAC isn’t working).
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The HVAC might not run when the user expects it to, due to programmed setbacks or off cycles, causing discomfort or the impression of a malfunction. Alternatively, it might turn off early or not reach setpoint due to an energy-saving schedule.
common_root_causes: Thermostat schedule programmed with economy set-backs (e.g., 85°F when not home)
Smart thermostat auto-away feature pausing conditioning
Day-of-week program mis-set (e.g., thinking it's a different day)
canonical_symptoms: System doesn’t come on at usual time or turns off at certain times unexpectedly
House is uncomfortable until a certain preset time passes or until manual override
Thermostat indicates it’s in a scheduled setback or hold
diagnostics.notes: Educating the homeowner on their thermostat’s schedule or resetting it to a simple, constant setting often solves these “faults,” which are not hardware issues at all.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Zone damper or zone controller malfunction
diagnostics.description: In a multi-zone HVAC system, one or more zone dampers are not operating correctly or the zone control board is failing to send proper signals, resulting in improper airflow to one or more zones.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: One zone may receive no heating/cooling (damper stuck closed) or too much (damper stuck open) regardless of thermostat demand. Overall system balance is disturbed; some areas get uncomfortable while others may overcondition.
common_root_causes: Zone damper actuator motor burned out or stuck
Faulty zone control board or relay not energizing damper
Thermostat in that zone not communicating with controller
canonical_symptoms: A particular zone (room or area) never reaches temperature while others do
Airflow can be heard in ducts but not delivered to the zone (damper not opening)
Zone calls for conditioning but equipment does not respond correctly (especially if zone controller logic fails)
diagnostics.notes: Zoned systems add complexity. Troubleshooting involves confirming each zone thermostat's call is recognized by the panel and that each damper moves freely when commanded. Manual override levers on dampers can help diagnose if it's an actuator issue vs. control issue.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Communication failure (e.g., thermostat to equipment or VRF controllers)
diagnostics.description: A communication bus or link between control components has failed. In VRF or modern systems, this could be the communication between indoor and outdoor units or between thermostat and control module.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The system may shut down or go into a fault mode because control signals are not being exchanged. In some cases, only certain parts of the system respond (e.g., some VRF indoor units offline). Error codes or blinking lights often accompany communication failures.
common_root_causes: Broken or shorted communication wiring (RS485, etc.)
Address conflict or duplication on the network
Failed communication module or control board
canonical_symptoms: Indoor units unresponsive in a VRF system (often with error code on controller)
Thermostat indicates it’s not connected to system (for wireless or communicating thermostats)
System in standby with communication error code
diagnostics.notes: Communications issues in complex systems may require specialized tools or vendor support to diagnose. Ensuring proper wiring terminations and addresses are the first steps. Rebooting systems sometimes clears temporary comm faults.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Thermostat sensor miscalibrated or poorly located
diagnostics.description: The thermostat’s temperature sensor is reading incorrectly or is installed in a location that doesn’t represent the true space conditions (e.g., in direct sunlight or in the path of a supply vent), causing improper system cycling.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The HVAC might short cycle or run excessively, depending on the misread. For instance, a thermostat in a hot spot will turn off the AC too late (overcooling other areas), whereas if it’s in a cold draft, it might turn off the heat prematurely. Comfort is inconsistent.
common_root_causes: Thermostat mounted in direct sun or near heat-producing electronics
Thermostat on an exterior wall or in the path of HVAC supply airflow
Out-of-calibration sensor within the thermostat (age or defect)
canonical_symptoms: Room temperatures feel different from thermostat setting
HVAC cycles are either too short or too long relative to maintaining comfort
Thermostat temperature reading differs significantly from other thermometers in the room
diagnostics.notes: The best fix is relocating the thermostat to a more representative location or using remote temperature sensors. Some smart thermostats allow sensor calibration adjustments by a few degrees as well.
evidence_snippets: If it’s placed in direct sunlight, near a heat source (like a lamp or TV), or directly in the path of a supply vent, it will get false readings and disrupt normal operation:contentReference[oaicite:24]{index=24}.

diagnostics.description: A temperature sensor within the HVAC system (not the main thermostat, but e.g., evaporator coil freeze sensor, outdoor temp sensor, room sensor in VRF) is malfunctioning, giving incorrect readings or none at all.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The system might behave improperly: for example, a bad coil sensor could falsely trip a freeze protection and stop cooling, or a bad outdoor sensor might disable heat pump defrost or economizer operation. The system may throw an error code or simply not run optimally.
common_root_causes: Sensor element drifted out of calibration or failed open/short
Damage to sensor wiring or connections
Corrosion or moisture ingress affecting the sensor
canonical_symptoms: System shuts off cooling even though coil isn’t cold (false freeze alarm)
Heat pump not defrosting or going to backup heat unnecessarily
Error code indicating a sensor out of range
diagnostics.notes: Sensor faults often generate diagnostic codes in modern equipment. The repair is typically to replace the sensor. In the interim, some systems allow bypassing certain sensors for testing (e.g., jumpering a freeze stat) to confirm diagnosis.

diagnostics.description: A pressure transducer or mechanical pressure switch in the system is giving a false reading or is stuck open/closed, leading to incorrect system control or nuisance trips.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: If a high-pressure or low-pressure switch is faulty, it might shut the system down even when pressures are normal (or fail to shut it down when there's a real problem). A faulty transducer could feed wrong data to a control system, causing improper modulation or triggering alarms.
common_root_causes: Switch contacts worn out or sensor diaphragm damaged
Sensor calibration drift or clog in the sensor port
Electrical failure or wiring issue to the sensor
canonical_symptoms: Unit randomly shuts off with pressure alarm despite normal refrigerant charge
System runs under dangerous pressure conditions without tripping (if switch stuck)
Controller displays implausible pressure readings
diagnostics.notes: A manual gauge reading is the gold standard to verify pressure sensor accuracy. If a pressure switch is suspect, it can sometimes be temporarily bypassed for testing (with caution). Ultimately replacement of the sensor/switch resolves the issue.

diagnostics.description: A humidity sensor (in a thermostat or separate humidistat/ventilation control) is not reading correctly or is stuck, which can affect dehumidification control or ventilation systems.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: If the sensor under-reads, a dehumidifier or reheat might not turn on, leading to high indoor humidity. If it over-reads, the system might over-dehumidify or run unnecessarily. It could also affect economizer operation if enthalpy controls are used.
common_root_causes: Dust or fouling on the sensor element
Electronic sensor drift or failure
Wiring fault causing sensor to read out of range
canonical_symptoms: High indoor humidity despite system supposed to control it (sensor not triggering dehumidification)
Ventilation systems not bringing enough outside air due to false humidity readings
Humidistat shows constant 99% or 0% (stuck reading)
diagnostics.notes: Humidity sensors often need periodic calibration. If one fails, replacement is straightforward. In critical environments, cross-checking with a psychrometer can confirm a sensor fault.

diagnostics.description: The flame sensor (flame rectification probe) is not detecting the burner flame, usually due to being coated in soot/oxide or because it has failed, causing the control to shut off the gas for safety.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The furnace or boiler ignites but then shuts off the gas within a few seconds, as the flame sensor does not register the flame. The system may attempt this ignition cycle multiple times before locking out, resulting in no sustained heat output.
common_root_causes: Sensor rod is coated with carbon or oxidation, insulating it
Poor grounding or electrical connection to sensor circuit
Sensor cracked or otherwise failed
canonical_symptoms: Furnace lights then shuts off quickly (in 1-5 seconds)
Furnace might retry ignition several times then go into lockout
No heat with a blinking error code (often indicating 'flame failure')
diagnostics.notes: The typical fix is cleaning the flame sensor with steel wool or fine sandpaper to restore good conductivity. If cleaning doesn’t help, or if the sensor’s ceramic is cracked, replacing the flame sensor is the next step.
evidence_snippets: If the furnace flame sensor fails to detect flame, the burner will shut off after a few seconds:contentReference[oaicite:25]{index=25}, resulting in the furnace not staying lit.

diagnostics.description: The furnace’s high-temperature limit safety switch has tripped (opened) because the furnace overheated, typically due to lack of airflow. This cuts power to the burners to prevent damage or hazards.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The furnace burners will shut off prematurely, often after only a short burn, while the blower may continue to run (to cool the heat exchanger). Heating is intermittent or insufficient as the furnace cycles off on the limit.
common_root_causes: Dirty air filter or blocked return causing reduced airflow
Blower motor failure or running below speed, so heat isn’t carried away
Closed/restricted supply vents or undersized duct causing heat buildup
canonical_symptoms: Furnace starts heating but stops after a couple of minutes, then possibly restarts and repeats
Rapid on/off cycling of the furnace (short heating cycles)
Furnace warm air is initially hot then turns cool as limit trips and blower keeps running
diagnostics.notes: Frequently caused by airflow issues – the first check is the filter and blower operation. The limit switch itself could weaken if it trips too often, so once the root cause is fixed, the switch may need replacement if it became overly sensitive or damaged.
evidence_snippets: A dirty filter or other airflow issue can cause the furnace to overheat, tripping the high-limit switch and shutting the burner off to prevent damage:contentReference[oaicite:26]{index=26}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Furnace pressure switch failed or tubing blocked
diagnostics.description: The pressure switch in the furnace, which ensures proper inducer operation and venting, is not closing as expected. This could be due to a malfunctioning switch, a blockage in the flue or condensate line, or the inducer not creating enough vacuum.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The furnace will not ignite because the control does not get the “all clear” signal from the pressure switch that the inducer is establishing draft. The inducer motor may run for a while then the furnace shuts down with an error. No heat is produced.
common_root_causes: Blocked vent pipe or intake (leaves, debris, snow, etc.) preventing proper draft
Condensate from a high-efficiency furnace clogging the pressure switch tubing or drain
Pressure switch diaphragm failure or calibration drift (opening at wrong pressure)
Inducer motor issue leading to inadequate vacuum
canonical_symptoms: Furnace inducer runs but burners never ignite
Multiple attempts at start then furnace goes into safety lockout (often blinking code for pressure switch)
No ignition flame and a code indicating a venting issue
diagnostics.notes: Technicians will check that the flue is clear and that the inducer and its ports are not clogged. Gently blowing/sucking on the pressure switch tube can test the switch. Replacing the pressure switch might be necessary if it’s proven faulty, but often the root cause is a blockage or condensate issue.

diagnostics.description: The safety float switch in the condensate drain pan or line has tripped due to a high water level, usually from a clogged condensate drain, and it has turned off the cooling system to prevent water overflow.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The air conditioner stops cooling entirely (outdoor unit often shuts off) even though the thermostat is calling for cooling. The blower might still run, but no cold air is produced, as the system has been disabled by the safety switch.
common_root_causes: Clogged condensate drain line (algae, dirt buildup)
Kinked or improperly pitched condensate drain causing backup
Failed condensate pump (if one is used) leading to filled reservoir
canonical_symptoms: AC was cooling but then stopped; water seen in drain pan or floor
System runs briefly then shuts off, repeatedly (if float opening/closing as water level fluctuates)
No cooling and upon inspection the secondary drain pan is full of water
diagnostics.notes: Clearing the blockage in the drain and resetting (or drying out) the pan will allow the AC to run again. It’s advisable to flush the drain with proper methods (vacuum or cleaning solution) and install safety switches if not present to avoid ceiling damage, etc.
evidence_snippets: Many AC systems have a float switch that will shut the system off if the condensate drain is clogged and water backs up:contentReference[oaicite:27]{index=27}. This prevents flooding but leaves you without cooling until the blockage is cleared.

diagnostics.description: The boiler’s low-water cutoff switch has activated because the water level or pressure in the boiler dropped below a safe threshold, so the boiler burner is shut down to prevent dry firing.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The boiler will not fire at all while this safety is open. The building will get no heat from the boiler. Often an indicator light or alarm is present on the boiler control when low water is detected.
common_root_causes: Water leak in the system causing loss of pressure/water
Failed automatic fill valve not replenishing water
Faulty low-water cutoff sensor (stuck open or scaled up giving false reading)
canonical_symptoms: Boiler is on (power) but not firing, pressure gauge very low
Need to manually add water frequently to restore operation
Boiler goes into lockout with a low-water fault code or alarm
diagnostics.notes: If the low water cutoff is tripped, the first step is to check system pressure/level and look for leaks or any issue with the feed valve. The LWCO device may need maintenance (blowing down float-style LWCOs to clear sediment) to ensure it's not a false trip.

diagnostics.description: The furnace or boiler fails to ignite at all because the ignition source (hot surface igniter or pilot light) is not functioning properly.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: No heat is produced because the burners do not light. The system will typically attempt to ignite several times then enter a safety lockout, resulting in the furnace/blower running cold or the boiler not firing.
common_root_causes: Hot surface igniter cracked or burnt out (open circuit, no glow)
Pilot orifice or line clogged (for standing pilot systems)
Ignition control module failure
canonical_symptoms: Furnace does not ignite at all (you hear clicks or see no glow, and no flame)
You might smell a little gas for a moment, then system shuts off for safety
System goes into retry mode or lockout without ever producing heat
diagnostics.notes: Hot surface igniters are a common wear item and often simply replacing the igniter solves the issue. For pilot systems, cleaning the pilot assembly or checking thermocouple (for older style) is essential. It's critical to ensure gas is present; if not, then the gas valve or supply might be the cause instead.
evidence_snippets: If your furnace has been working without any problems up to now and suddenly will not ignite, there’s a good chance that either the electronic ignition system has failed or that the standing pilot light has gone out:contentReference[oaicite:28]{index=28}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Gas valve not opening or gas supply issue
diagnostics.description: No gas is reaching the burners. This can occur if the gas supply is shut off or if the furnace’s gas valve fails to open when energized.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The furnace or boiler will not produce any flame at all, so no heat. You may have the ignition source activating (glow or spark), but since no gas flows, ignition won’t occur. The system typically will lock out after failing to detect flame.
common_root_causes: Manual gas shutoff valve closed (someone turned off the gas line)
Gas supply interruption from utility or empty propane tank
Faulty gas valve coil or control board not sending voltage to valve
canonical_symptoms: No flame present at all, even though igniter is working (and gas is supposed to be on)
You don’t smell any gas when you would normally smell a little during ignition (for systems without sealed combustion)
Furnace tries to ignite and fails repeatedly with a gas-related error code
diagnostics.notes: Always rule out that the gas is on to the furnace: check other gas appliances, and verify the gas cock is open. If gas is available and the igniter works, then focus on the gas valve or control board not opening it. Tap testing a gas valve (lightly tapping) sometimes frees a stuck valve, but replacement is the fix.
evidence_snippets: One of the most common reasons a furnace is not lighting is when your gas line is blocked or clogged. The furnace will not be able to get enough natural gas to start up:contentReference[oaicite:29]{index=29}.

diagnostics.description: The furnace or boiler burners have accumulated dirt, rust, or soot, which impedes proper gas flow and combustion. The flames may burn unevenly or not fully.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Ignition may be delayed or incomplete (causing booms or rollout), flame may be yellow or wavering, and combustion efficiency drops. Carbon monoxide production can increase due to improper burner combustion.
common_root_causes: Lack of regular maintenance (burners never cleaned)
Dust, lint, pet hair buildup in burner ports over time
Corrosion flakes from older heat exchangers clogging burner orifices
canonical_symptoms: There is a boom or popping sound when furnace starts (delayed ignition from clogged burners)
Flame is yellow/orange instead of steady blue
Exhaust CO levels higher than normal, soot accumulation
diagnostics.notes: Cleaning burners (by brushing or using compressed air) is often part of a tune-up. If burners are very corroded, they might need replacement. Ensuring a clean intake (air filter, etc.) can reduce dust buildup on burners as well.
evidence_snippets: Dirt accumulates on the burners of your HVAC system, preventing them from burning evenly and at the proper height... The flames may not completely burn when the burners are clogged with debris, creating a higher amount of carbon monoxide:contentReference[oaicite:30]{index=30}.

diagnostics.description: The furnace’s heat exchanger has developed a crack or hole. This is a serious condition as it can allow combustion gases (including carbon monoxide) to mix with indoor air and also affects burner operation.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The furnace may exhibit erratic burner flames (flame rollout when the blower comes on). It often triggers safety devices like the rollout switches. Worst case, carbon monoxide can leak into the home. Heating performance might drop, and the furnace might shut down on safety limits frequently.
common_root_causes: Metal fatigue from many heat cycles over years (especially if furnace overheated due to airflow issues)
Corrosion due to flue gases (particularly in older or poorly vented furnaces)
Manufacturing defect (less common, usually age-related in 10+ year old units)
canonical_symptoms: CO alarm triggering or fumes smell
Burners exhibit rollout when blower starts
Furnace shuts down via safety mechanisms (e.g., rollout or limit switches tripping) without obvious cause
diagnostics.notes: A cracked heat exchanger cannot be repaired; the heat exchanger or entire furnace must be replaced. Until that is done, the furnace should remain off due to the carbon monoxide risk.
evidence_snippets: An overheating furnace due to poor airflow can crack the heat exchanger, a serious safety hazard that can leak carbon monoxide:contentReference[oaicite:31]{index=31}.

diagnostics.description: The exhaust vent or chimney is obstructed, preventing combustion gases from properly venting out. This often triggers the furnace’s pressure switch or spill switches, and can lead to a hazardous spillage of flue gases.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The furnace or boiler may not ignite at all because the inducer cannot establish adequate draft (pressure switch stays open). In some cases, if it does fire, exhaust gases could spill into the area (very dangerous). Usually, the unit will shut itself down quickly for safety.
common_root_causes: Animal nests or debris (like leaves) blocking the flue pipe or chimney cap
Snow or ice blockage in exhaust (common in sidewall venting in winter)
Collapsed masonry or corrosion inside chimney reducing flow
canonical_symptoms: Pilot or burner won’t stay lit due to lack of draft
Exhaust smell or flame rollout around furnace during operation attempt
Pressure switch error code preventing startup
diagnostics.notes: This problem must be resolved before safely operating the furnace. Clearing the vent and possibly installing a proper chimney cap or screen to prevent recurrence is important. Technicians might also test for proper draft after repair.
evidence_snippets: Blocked chimneys or furnaces can prevent the draft motor from drawing in air. As a result, the igniter will not light:contentReference[oaicite:32]{index=32}.

diagnostics.description: The furnace’s draft inducer fan (which pulls combustion air through the heat exchanger and into the flue) is not operating due to motor failure or mechanical issue, so proper combustion airflow cannot be established.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The furnace will not ignite because the pressure switch won’t close (since the inducer isn’t creating the necessary vacuum). You may hear the furnace click on and perhaps a faint hum, but the inducer wheel doesn’t spin. No flame occurs and the system shuts down, often with a fault indication.
common_root_causes: Inducer motor winding burnt out (age or overheating)
Inducer motor stuck (bearings seized or foreign object in fan)
No power to inducer due to wiring/control board issue
canonical_symptoms: Inducer fan does not start at beginning of call for heat
Furnace doesn’t light at all and goes into lockout with an inducer/pressure switch error
Inducer motor is silent or just hums without spinning
diagnostics.notes: The inducer assembly often comes out with a few screws; a tech will verify the motor receives voltage when it should and see if it spins freely. Replacement of the inducer motor or entire inducer assembly is the fix.
evidence_snippets: If there is a strong draft in your basement or attic, or if you are experiencing high winds, the pilot light may not light. In addition, if your furnace has a draft motor or blower that is malfunctioning or dead, the pilot won’t light:contentReference[oaicite:33]{index=33}.

diagnostics.description: There is not enough fresh air for combustion, often due to a very tight mechanical room or a blocked combustion air intake, causing the flames to 'roll out' of the burner area seeking oxygen.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The furnace may experience flame rollout – flames coming out of the normal burner area – which trips the rollout safety switches and shuts off the furnace to prevent a fire hazard. The furnace will stop heating and typically requires manual reset of rollout switches.
common_root_causes: No combustion air vent in a confined space (sealed house or closet)
Return air leakage causing furnace area to depressurize relative to combustion zone
Blocked combustion air intake grill (for systems that have dedicated intake from outdoors)
canonical_symptoms: Flames visible outside the burner chamber or charring around burner compartment
Rollout switch tripped (manual reset switch needs resetting, indicating flame rollout occurred)
Boom or muffled ignition as flames are starved for air initially
diagnostics.notes: Solution involves providing proper ventilation/combustion air openings to the furnace area or clearing blockages. This might include opening louvers, installing grills/ducts for combustion air, or correcting negative pressure issues in the room.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Electric heat strips not working (burned out or relay failure)
diagnostics.description: In an electric furnace or heat pump auxiliary heat, the electric resistance heating elements are not energizing. This could be due to the elements themselves being burnt out, or a control/relay not turning them on.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: In pure electric furnaces: no heat at all, just fan running (blowing room-temperature air). In heat pumps: insufficient heat in cold weather or during defrost cycles because the auxiliary heat isn’t supplementing. The system struggles to maintain temperature.
common_root_causes: Heating element open-circuited (failed due to age or overheating)
Sequencer or contactor that controls the strips not functioning
Safety cutouts (like thermal limits on elements) tripped or failed open
canonical_symptoms: Thermostat calls for heat but only cool air comes out (in an electric furnace)
Heat pump runs but can’t keep up in very cold weather, indoor temp drops
Breaker trips when strips supposed to energize (could be shorted element)
diagnostics.notes: After confirming proper airflow (to avoid overheating new elements), the typical fix is to replace the faulty heating elements or the control sequencer/relay. It’s important to also verify that the high temperature limit controls are in circuit and functional.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Heat pump auxiliary heat stuck on or not engaging
diagnostics.description: The backup heating (electric resistive heat strips or gas furnace in a dual-fuel system) for a heat pump is not operating correctly – either it never comes on when needed, or it is running when it shouldn't (stuck on).
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: If stuck off: During very cold weather or defrost cycles, the heat pump alone may not maintain indoor temperature, resulting in cold indoor conditions. If stuck on: The auxiliary heat runs continuously, possibly even when the heat pump is cooling, leading to extremely high energy use and potentially overly hot air or simultaneous heating and cooling.
common_root_causes: Aux heat relay or contactor failed (open, not energizing strips)
Control board or balance point settings preventing aux heat engagement
Aux heat relay stuck closed (continuously energizing strips)
Thermostat wiring error causing AUX to be energized in wrong mode
canonical_symptoms: Home cannot reach set temperature in cold weather (aux heat never kicks in)
Unusually high electricity bills and overly warm air (aux heat running too often or even during cooling)
Heat pump seems to run cooling and heating at same time (if aux heat stuck on during AC)
diagnostics.notes: For stuck-off scenarios, the thermostat configuration or outdoor temperature lockout settings should be checked. For stuck-on, the control relay for aux heat likely needs replacement. Dual fuel systems could have control logic issues causing overlap of heat sources that need correction.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: System undersized for load or extreme conditions
diagnostics.description: The HVAC system’s capacity is too low for the space, or weather conditions exceed its design parameters, so it cannot maintain the set temperature on very hot or cold days.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: During peak weather (heat wave or cold snap), the system may run continuously at full output yet the indoor temperature drifts from the setpoint (too warm in summer, too cool in winter). The equipment itself is functioning normally but is simply maxed out.
common_root_causes: Initial design load underestimated or equipment selected too small
Significant changes to the home/building (addition, insulation removed) increasing the load
Extreme weather beyond typical ranges (e.g., record-breaking heat) temporarily exceeding capacity
canonical_symptoms: HVAC runs non-stop but cannot reach thermostat setting on very hot/cold days
Some rooms never get comfortable because the unit cannot deliver enough cooling/heating
Maybe an okay performance during moderate weather, but falls behind in extreme conditions
diagnostics.notes: Long term fix is to install a properly sized system or improve building insulation/heat gain (e.g., add insulation, shade windows). If extreme weather is rare, it might be acceptable to the user to have a few days of not meeting setpoint. However, ensuring everything else (charge, airflow) is optimal is important.
evidence_snippets: Under moderate conditions, you may not notice any issues with an undersized air conditioner. However, as temperatures rise outside, your AC may run for long periods of time and struggle to keep you cool:contentReference[oaicite:34]{index=34}.

diagnostics.description: The HVAC system has more capacity than required for the space, causing it to satisfy the thermostat quickly and turn off before sufficient runtime (especially for AC) to dehumidify or evenly condition the space.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Short and frequent on/off cycling, uneven temperature distribution, higher indoor humidity (in cooling mode) because the system does not run long enough to remove moisture. It also increases wear on components due to frequent starts.
common_root_causes: Incorrect equipment sizing during installation (oversized tonnage or BTUs)
Significant improvement to home insulation or window upgrades after sizing (making system effectively too large)
Multi-stage or modulating equipment not set up to run at lower stages
canonical_symptoms: Very short cooling/heating cycles (system turns off after just a few minutes)
House cools quickly but feels clammy or damp in summer
Notable temperature swings and unit constantly turning on and off
diagnostics.notes: Solutions include using dehumidifiers, adding thermostatic delay settings, or ultimately replacing the system with correctly sized equipment. Zoning or advanced controls can mitigate some oversizing issues by keeping the system running longer at lower outputs if it’s multi-stage.
evidence_snippets: It was found that 46% of the units had improper refrigerant charge, 64% of the units had economizer problems, 42% of the units had airflow problems, 58% of the... (This study only includes prevalence of faults related to refrigerant, evaporator airflow, and economizer operation:contentReference[oaicite:35]{index=35}.
Heat exchanger faults can cause severe problems and damage, including dangerous issues like carbon monoxide leaks in the furnace:contentReference[oaicite:36]{index=36}.
An oversized system can result in reduced cooling capacity. Ironically, an overcharged system can lead to reduced cooling capacity:contentReference[oaicite:37]{index=37}.
A dirty HVAC air filter can restrict airflow in your HVAC system. Proper airflow is essential to provide cool air:contentReference[oaicite:38]{index=38}.

Field studies have demonstrated that common faults, namely inadequate refrigerant charge and insufficient evaporator airflow, were present in 50–72% of CACs and ASHPs inspected:contentReference[oaicite:39]{index=39}.
If your AC is running but not cooling, it could be due to a dirty air filter, incorrect thermostat settings, a malfunctioning thermostat, a refrigerant leak...:contentReference[oaicite:40]{index=40}

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Refrigerant lines kinked or improperly sized
diagnostics.description: The refrigerant line-set has physical kinks or was installed with an incorrect diameter or length, affecting refrigerant flow and oil return.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Restricted or suboptimal flow of refrigerant can reduce efficiency and capacity. A kink acts like a partial blockage, causing low suction pressure and potentially compressor overheating. Wrong line sizing might lead to inadequate oil return or performance losses.
common_root_causes: Line set bent too sharply during installation (kinked copper)
Using smaller-than-recommended line diameter to save cost or ease install
Excessively long line without proper traps or larger sizing
canonical_symptoms: Reduced cooling capacity despite correct charge
Unusual compressor noises (if oil trapping issues)
Pressure readings not matching expected values (pressure drop across kink)
diagnostics.notes: If kinks are accessible, sometimes they can be fixed by replacing that section or brazing in a coupling after cutting out the kink. If undersized lines are the issue, a line-set replacement may be needed for full performance, especially on long runs.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Outdoor coil fins damaged (hail or impact)
diagnostics.description: The aluminum fins on the outdoor condenser coil are flattened or damaged over a significant area, such as from hail strikes or mechanical impact, reducing heat transfer and airflow.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Similar to a dirty coil, the damaged fins impede airflow and heat rejection. Head pressures rise, efficiency falls, and capacity can drop. On hot days, the system may struggle or trip on high pressure if enough fin area is flattened.
common_root_causes: Hail storm hitting the condenser
Pressure washing with too much force bending fins
Vandalism or accidental impact (e.g., weed whacker, lawn mower throwing debris)
canonical_symptoms: Poor cooling performance, especially in high outdoor temperatures
Higher head pressure and compressor amp draw than normal
Visible fin flattening upon inspection of the condenser
diagnostics.notes: Minor fin damage can be combed out with a fin comb tool to straighten the fins. Severe damage might necessitate replacing the coil or entire condenser. Installing hail guards can prevent future hail damage without significantly affecting airflow.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Thermostat or system turned off unintentionally
diagnostics.description: There is no actual equipment fault; the HVAC system is not running simply because it was manually turned off or set improperly by the user (or someone in the household), albeit unknowingly.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The system remains off, providing no cooling or heating, leading the user to believe there is a malfunction. Once the control is returned to the correct setting (system On/Auto), normal operation resumes.
common_root_causes: Accidental switch-off of the thermostat (set to Off)
HVAC circuit turned off at breaker or disconnect by mistake
Programmable thermostat with hold or vacation mode left engaged
canonical_symptoms: HVAC completely unresponsive, but no apparent mechanical issues
System found in off mode on thermostat or power supply turned off
After simply turning it on, system runs normally
diagnostics.notes: This is an education opportunity. No repair needed, but the user is advised on how to check basic settings. Technicians often mark service calls like these as "NTF" (no trouble found).

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: System operating normally but unable to keep up in extreme weather
diagnostics.description: The system is functioning as designed, but due to extremely high (or low) outdoor temperatures or other unusual conditions, it appears to underperform. Essentially, there's no mechanical fault; the circumstances are beyond the system’s design limits.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The HVAC might run at full capacity continuously and still not maintain the desired indoor temperature. The unit isn’t short cycling or showing errors—just running non-stop and the indoor temperature is drifting from setpoint during the peak conditions.
common_root_causes: Heat wave or cold snap far beyond typical design day conditions
Unusual interior gains (party with many people, lots of cooking, etc.) that temporarily overwhelm system
System design exactly at edge of requirements—under most days it's fine, but not at extremes
canonical_symptoms: House gets a few degrees warmer than setpoint on the hottest day of the year despite AC running constantly
No mechanical issues found; pressure and amperages normal, just running continuously
Indoor humidity might rise due to long-term continuous run (in cooling) without cycling
diagnostics.notes: In these cases, the 'fix' could be temporary measures like using supplemental cooling (window AC or portable unit) during extreme events, or simply understanding that it's a transient condition. It’s important to confirm the system truly is performing normally and not misdiagnosed when it actually has a small fault causing the shortfall.

symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: air from the vents remains cool when heating is on
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Check if the furnace burners are igniting. A failed igniter or pilot will prevent the furnace from producing heat.
symptom_mappings.notes: If the furnace's ignition system fails, the blower may circulate air that hasn't been heated. For example, a cracked hot surface igniter or an extinguished pilot will result in no flame and thus cold air.

symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: furnace cycles off before reaching the set temperature
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: This often indicates the furnace is overheating. Check for airflow restrictions like dirty filters that might cause a high-limit trip.

symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: furnace fails to ignite entirely (no flame)
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Ensure the gas supply is on. If it is, the furnace may have a gas valve or ignition control issue preventing it from lighting.
symptom_mappings.notes: A common cause is no gas flow – for instance, the gas valve could be closed or the line could be blocked:contentReference[oaicite:82]{index=82}. If gas is available, the ignition system (pilot/igniter) or a safety switch might be at fault.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: loud banging or rattling from blower
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: unusual banging or rattling noises are heard during system operation
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Turn off the system and inspect the blower wheel and motor mounts. A loose or broken part can cause banging or rattling sounds.
symptom_mappings.notes: A loose blower wheel or motor mount can create a banging noise as it strikes the housing. Ensuring all screws and components are tight can resolve this. Debris in the blower or outdoor fan can also cause rattling.

symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: a high-pitched squealing or screeching noise comes from the HVAC system
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: This often comes from a blower motor or belt issue. Check if the belt is worn or the motor bearings need lubrication or replacement.
symptom_mappings.notes: A worn fan belt or dry motor bearings frequently cause a screeching sound. In belt-driven blowers, replacing or adjusting the belt is a common fix. Motor bearing issues may require motor replacement or lubrication.

symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: a loud 'boom' or popping sound occurs when the furnace starts up
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: This usually indicates delayed ignition. Inspect and clean the burners, and check the ignition system (igniter or pilot) to ensure timely lighting of gas.
symptom_mappings.notes: A boom at startup often means gas is building up before ignition, then igniting all at once. Cleaning clogged burners and ensuring the igniter/pilot lights promptly will typically solve the issue:contentReference[oaicite:88]{index=88}.
