symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: indoor humidity remains high despite cooling operation
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: High humidity can be due to short cooling cycles or insufficient dehumidification. Consider if the AC might be oversized or if the fan is set to continuous 'On' (which can re-evaporate moisture).
symptom_mappings.notes: If an AC unit cools the air too quickly (as in an oversized system) it won't dehumidify effectively. The result is a cool but humid home. Ensuring longer cycle times or using a dehumidification mode can help.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: one room doesn't cool like others
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: one or more rooms are not receiving adequate conditioning compared to the rest
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Inspect the ductwork for that room. There could be a disconnection or leak. Also ensure the register is open and unobstructed.
symptom_mappings.notes: A major duct leak or a closed damper to that room will result in significantly less air reaching it:contentReference[oaicite:91]{index=91}. Alternatively, the distribution system might be unbalanced or that zone's control could be malfunctioning.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: burning dust smell when heat comes on
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: a burning dust odor is noticed when the heating system starts
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: If it's the first time using heat in a while, a burning dust smell can be normal. Dust accumulates on the heat exchanger or elements and burns off initially.
symptom_mappings.notes: A brief burning smell at the first heating cycle of the season is typically just dust burning off and should dissipate quickly. If it persists or is strong, check the furnace for dirt or issues.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: AC turns on and off every few minutes
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: the air conditioner compressor turns on and off in very short intervals
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Short cycling can be caused by an oversized system or a control issue. Also check if the unit might be shutting off on a safety (like high pressure) then quickly restarting.
symptom_mappings.notes: Oversized AC units will short cycle because they satisfy the thermostat too quickly:contentReference[oaicite:94]{index=94}. Other causes include refrigerant charge issues or safety controls cutting out the compressor prematurely. This behavior can lead to poor humidity control and extra wear on the compressor.

symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: the furnace burners ignite but then shut off shortly after
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: A flame sensor issue is likely. The sensor may be dirty or faulty, causing the system to shut off the gas since it 'thinks' no flame is present.
symptom_mappings.notes: If the flame sensor does not detect the burner flame, the furnace will cut off gas for safety:contentReference[oaicite:97]{index=97}. Cleaning the sensor with fine sandpaper often resolves this if it's just oxidized.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: boiler fires but radiators are cold
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: the boiler is operating but heat is not reaching some or all radiators
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Air in the system can block water flow to radiators. Bleed the radiators to see if air discharge restores heating.
symptom_mappings.notes: Air pockets are a common cause of radiators not heating in a hydronic system. Gurgling noises are a telltale sign:contentReference[oaicite:100]{index=100}. Regular bleeding may be required to remove trapped air.

symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: the boiler’s pressure relief valve is discharging water
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: This usually means the boiler pressure is too high. A waterlogged expansion tank is a common culprit, causing pressure to spike when the boiler heats up.
symptom_mappings.notes: If the expansion tank loses its air cushion (for example, a failed bladder), the boiler pressure can rise excessively during heating, lifting the relief valve:contentReference[oaicite:103]{index=103}. Recharging or replacing the expansion tank typically resolves this.

symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: the outdoor unit/compressor is much louder than normal
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: A loud compressor can indicate internal wear or liquid refrigerant flooding. Check refrigerant charge and compressor health.
symptom_mappings.notes: Overcharged systems or liquid slugging can make the compressor noisy:contentReference[oaicite:106]{index=106}, as can mechanical wear. It's worth checking pressures and listening for any knocking or rattling sounds from the compressor.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: one zone not cooling in office
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: a particular zone in a multi-zone system is not cooling/heating
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Verify that the zone's damper and thermostat are working. The damper might be stuck or its actuator failed.
symptom_mappings.notes: In zoned systems, a single zone not conditioning often points to a zone damper not opening or a control issue for that zone. Electrical or actuator failures are common culprits.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: carbon monoxide detector triggered with furnace on
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: carbon monoxide alarm triggers during furnace operation
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Shut off the furnace immediately and ventilate. A cracked heat exchanger or flue issue could be allowing combustion gases into the home.
symptom_mappings.notes: A cracked heat exchanger can leak dangerous CO into the air:contentReference[oaicite:109]{index=109}. Blocked flues or flame rollout can also produce CO. This is a critical safety issue requiring professional inspection.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: flames are coming out of the furnace
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: flames roll out of the furnace burner area during operation
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Shut off the furnace. Flame rollout usually means the combustion gases aren't venting properly. Check for a blocked flue or lack of combustion air.
symptom_mappings.notes: When flue gases can't escape (e.g., due to a chimney obstruction), they can force flames out of the burner chamber. This trips safety switches and is very dangerous:contentReference[oaicite:111]{index=111}. The cause must be corrected before safe operation.

symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: the vents or ducts emit a whistling sound when the system is running
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: A whistling vent usually means air is being forced through a small opening. Check for closed dampers or undersized return grills.
symptom_mappings.notes: Whistling noises indicate high static pressure. Common reasons are closed supply registers, a too-small return, or a very dirty filter causing the system to suck air through any tiny gaps.

symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: unusually high energy consumption by the HVAC system
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: A common cause is auxiliary heat running excessively. Also ensure system efficiency isn't compromised by issues like refrigerant leaks or duct leaks.
symptom_mappings.notes: If electric resistance heaters (aux heat) get stuck on, energy use skyrockets. A refrigerant leak can also cause longer runtimes, raising bills. Sudden increases should be investigated for such faults.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: boiler keeps turning on and off
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: the boiler turns on and off more frequently than normal
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Frequent boiler cycling can indicate the boiler is oversized or a control issue. Check the thermostat or control settings and whether the boiler is exceeding the heat demand quickly.
symptom_mappings.notes: In commercial boilers, short cycling wastes energy and stresses the system:contentReference[oaicite:113]{index=113}. It often happens when capacity is too high for the load or if controls aren't set up for proper differential. Ensuring proper sizing or adding a buffer tank can help.
